items.NAME: ü§ñ marp.brain
items.TITLE: üß† Raspberry Pi 5
items.MOTTO: 4-axis stepper control with dual input via USB joystick or Wi-Fi Direct UDP, low-latency H.264 video streaming & auto-stop safety
items.TEXT:
Raspberry Pi 5 Robot Controller
Drives a 4-axis robot (2 drive steppers + 2 turret steppers) using lgpio for precise GPIO timing. Written in Python (74.2%); C++ (10.0%); Shell (8.2%); HTML (5.7%); built with CMake.

Features:
  • Dual Input ‚Äî Seamlessly switches between local USB joystick (Xbox) and network UDP packets (JSON on port 5005) with automatic failover
  • Wi-Fi Direct ‚Äî Acts as Group Owner hotspot (DIRECT-xx-Robot-Pi5) for field connection without a router; DHCP via dnsmasq
  • Safety ‚Äî Auto-stops all motors if network connection is lost for >1 second
  • Video Multiplexer ‚Äî Unified MJPEG stream on port 5600 with hot-swap between sources (Pi Camera; Kinect RGB; IR; depth map); configurable resolution and quality
  • Kinect Support ‚Äî Vendors libfreenect as a submodule for RGB/depth/IR; accelerometer; and motor/LED control
  • Systemd Integration ‚Äî Auto-starts wifi-direct; stepper-controller; and video-stream services on boot
Hardware Pinout (BCM GPIO):
  • Left Drive: 5/6/13 ¬∑ Right Drive: 19/26/21
  • Turret Pan: 23/24/25 ¬∑ Turret Tilt: 12/16/20
  • Activity LED: GPIO 18
Diagrams: High-Level Wiring; Data Flow; User Story; System Architecture (Mermaid-sourced)
Dependencies: liblgpio-dev; nlohmann-json3-dev; dnsmasq; rpicam-vid; libfreenect

items.NAME: üïπÔ∏è marp.gamepad
items.TITLE: üéÆ Valve Steamdeck
items.MOTTO: Wireless teleoperation with real-time video feed, native Steam Deck & Xbox controller support via Unity's Input System
items.TEXT:
MARP Gamepad ‚Äî Wireless Teleoperation Client
A Unity 6.0 client-side control application designed primarily for the Valve Steam Deck; enabling wireless teleoperation and real-time video streaming over a local Wi-Fi network. Written in ShaderLab (44.8%); C# (43.9%); HLSL (9.2%); PowerShell (1.7%); Shell (0.4%).

Features:
  • Wireless Teleoperation ‚Äî Control the robot's mobility; head movements; and expressive outputs over shared local Wi-Fi
  • Live Video Feed ‚Äî Receives and displays real-time MJPEG stream from the robot's onboard cameras/sensors at http://192.168.4.1:5600/stream.mjpg
  • Input Support ‚Äî Native Steam Deck controls and Xbox Elite Controller via Unity's Input System package; dual joysticks for drive (left) and turret (right)
  • Source Switching ‚Äî Switch between Pi Camera; Kinect RGB; IR; and depth feeds from the client via HTTP or TCP socket
Hardware Specs:
  • Steam Deck: 5‚Äì20V USB-C PD; ‚â§3.0A; ‚â§45W; 11.7" √ó 4.6" √ó 1.9"
  • Xbox Controller: 5V; ‚â§1.5A; ‚â§7.5W (optional/dev input)
Control Protocol: UDP JSON packets to 192.168.4.1:5005 ‚Äî {joysticks: {left: [x;y]; right: [x;y]}} with values from -1.0 to 1.0
Build Target: Linux (Steam Deck architecture)
Deployment: build_deploy.ps1 (PowerShell) and launch.sh for automated build and deploy

items.NAME: ‚òÑÔ∏è BitNaughts
items.MOTTO: Code Gamified!
items.TEXT:
Parent Repository & Submodule Orchestrator
BitNaughts is an educational programming video game that teaches players coding concepts through interactive gameplay. The parent repo ties together the full project via Git submodules ‚Äî linking bitnaughts.unity (game client); bitnaughts.github.io (WebGL front-end); and bitnaughts.mainframe (cloud back-end).

items.NAME: üéÆ Unity
items.TITLE: Unity 6.0
items.MOTTO: Cross-platform game interface
items.TEXT:
Unity Game Client
The core game application built in Unity 6.0 (100% C#). Players navigate a spaceship; dock at planets; and solve programming challenges through an in-game terminal that interprets assembly-style instructions.

Submodule Architecture:
  • Assets ‚Äî Sprites; audio; and visual assets
  • UI/UX ‚Äî Interface design and user experience components
  • Components ‚Äî Modular game systems (navigation; docking; inventory)
  • C# Interpreter ‚Äî The embedded language interpreter engine
  • WebGLNativeInputField ‚Äî Custom input handling for WebGL builds
Contributors: 4 (Mutilar; botnaughts; vva0; nt314p)

items.NAME: üë®‚Äçüíª Interpreter
items.TITLE: C#
items.MOTTO: Stepping through each OP Code of abstracted languages
items.TEXT:
Assembly Interpreter Engine
The core language processing engine written in C# that powers BitNaughts' in-game programming challenges. Players write assembly-level OP codes which this interpreter steps through instruction-by-instruction.

Architecture:
  • Interpreter.cs ‚Äî Main execution loop; parses and executes OP code instructions sequentially
  • Instruction.cs ‚Äî Data model representing individual assembly instructions (opcode + operands)
  • Variable.cs ‚Äî Register and memory variable management for the virtual machine
  • ColorCoder.cs ‚Äî Syntax highlighting for the in-game terminal; color-codes keywords; registers; and literals
Designed as a Git submodule consumed by bitnaughts.unity; enabling modular development of the language engine independent of the game client.

items.NAME: üì∫ bitnaughts.io
items.TITLE: WebGL
items.MOTTO: Play the demo in your browser!
items.TEXT:
WebGL Front-End ‚Äî bitnaughts.io
The web-hosted runtime that serves Unity WebGL builds directly in the browser.

Pages:
  • play.html ‚Äî Primary single-player game interface
  • duo.html ‚Äî Multiplayer / co-op mode
  • alpha.html ‚Äî Alpha testing build
  • portal.html ‚Äî Landing page and navigation portal
Key Directories:
  • Build/ ‚Äî Compiled Unity WebGL artifacts (.unityweb; .json; UnityLoader.js)
  • StreamingAssets/ ‚Äî Runtime data files loaded by Unity at play-time
  • TemplateData/ ‚Äî Loading screen and progress bar assets
  • assets/ ‚Äî Static images and media
  • documentation/ ‚Äî Project docs and guides

items.NAME: üé§ Voice
items.TITLE: Narrator
items.MOTTO: Forays into A.I. narration
items.TEXT:
A.I. Voice Narration ‚Äî TorToiSe TTS
A fork of neonbjb/tortoise-tts adapted for in-game AI narration. TorToiSe is a multi-voice text-to-speech system that uses an autoregressive decoder paired with a diffusion model to generate highly realistic speech.

Capabilities:
  • Multi-voice synthesis ‚Äî clone and generate speech in different character voices from short reference clips
  • High-quality prosody and intonation via autoregressive sequence modeling
  • Diffusion-based audio refinement for natural-sounding output
  • Configurable voice presets for distinct in-game characters and narrators
Use Case: Generate dynamic AI narration for BitNaughts' tutorial sequences; mission briefings; and in-game lore ‚Äî replacing static audio recordings with procedurally generated speech.
License: Apache-2.0

items.NAME: üì° Mainframe
items.TITLE: Azure
items.MOTTO: Serverless cloud resources for persistence
items.TEXT:
Serverless Back-End ‚Äî bitnaughts.azurewebsites.net
An Azure Function App written in C# that provides cloud persistence for multiplayer game state. Hosted as a serverless endpoint with two HTTP-triggered functions.

Functions:
  • Ping() ‚Äî Multiplayer state sync via MongoDB; upserts player data keyed by name; returns all other players' state (uses ‚ôñ delimiter). Connection secured with TLS 1.2 and TTL indexes for automatic document expiry (expireAfterSeconds: 10).
  • Mainframe() ‚Äî Git-based persistence layer; clones bitnaughts.db repo to temp storage; reads/writes player save files as .txt; then commits and pushes changes back via LibGit2Sharp.
Stack: Azure Functions; MongoDB (CosmosDB-compatible); LibGit2Sharp; Newtonsoft.Json

items.TITLE: Robotics

items.NAME: üì¶ CSE 165
items.TITLE: OOP

items.TEXT:

items.NAME: üåê CSE 160
items.TITLE: Networks
items.MOTTO: Protocols that connect the world
items.TEXT:

items.NAME: üóÉÔ∏è CSE 111

items.NAME: ‚öôÔ∏è CSE 31

items.NAME: üìö CSE 30

items.NAME: ü§ñ MARP
items.TITLE: Personal Project
items.MOTTO: 4-axis robot with wireless teleoperation & real-time video streaming
items.TEXT:
The Idea

MARP is a 4-axis robot platform with wireless teleoperation and real-time video streaming: a Raspberry Pi 5 brain, a Valve Steam Deck controller, and a modular architecture split across focused repos.

How It Works

The Pi 5 runs marp.brain: 4-axis stepper control (2 drive + 2 turret) via lgpio, dual input switching between USB joystick and Wi-Fi Direct UDP, MJPEG video multiplexing across Pi Camera and Kinect sources, and auto-stop safety on connection loss. The Steam Deck runs marp.gamepad: a Unity 6.0 teleoperation client with live video feed, native controller support, and source switching. Wi-Fi Direct lets the Pi act as its own hotspot for field operation without a router.

The Grind

Two repos, two platforms, one control loop. The Pi side is Python/C++ with systemd services for boot-ready deployment; the Deck side is C#/ShaderLab with automated build-and-deploy scripts. Kinect integration vendors libfreenect as a submodule for RGB, depth, IR, accelerometer, and motor/LED control.

items.NAME: üìñ DuskRoseCodex
items.TITLE: Personal Project
items.MOTTO: Satirical Vorthos mythopoeia bound in crimson thread
items.TEXT:
The Idea

The Dusk Rose Codex transforms two Magic: The Gathering Commander decks into satirical Vorthos scripture. Two primordial gods ‚Äî Order and Chaos ‚Äî spawn three factions (Faithful, Greedy, Defiant), except faith doesn't save, wealth doesn't protect, and rebellion doesn't free. What culminates is wry mythopoeia that subverts tired clich√©s, hand-bound in crimson thread as a physical codex.

How It Works

The project spans two tools. DeckLore is a vanilla JS web app (ES modules, Scryfall API, MTG Fandom wiki scraper) that transforms deck CSV exports into interactive narrative experiences: grid visualization with category grouping, card-by-card lore tagging (protagonist, ally, antagonist, artifact, location, event), a chapter-based narrative builder with drag-and-drop cards and woven flavor text, and a wiki discovery system that scrapes character histories, card references, and story appearances with 24-hour localStorage caching. The Codex itself is typeset in LaTeX with Cinzel Decorative headings and Old Standard TT body text, illustrated with AI-generated card art (ComfyUI pipelines for style transfer, frame interpolation, and transform workflows), and compiled into a hand-bound PDF. A companion video (3:26) presents the finished artifact.

The Grind

DeckLore's architecture is fully modular: csvParser.js, scryfallApi.js, cardStore.js, and wikiScraper.js in the data layer; Card.js, LoreEntry.js, and DeckLore.js as models; 14 view components from DeckGrid to BibleView to WikiDiscoveryView. The wiki scraper extracts Represented In, Associated Cards, Depicted In, and Quoted In references, highlighting cards that appear in your deck. The LaTeX pipeline went through multiple iterations ‚Äî the_nobles_bible.tex, the_nobles_bible_clean.tex, the_nobles_bible_phyrexian.tex ‚Äî before the Phyrexian-transliterated final version. Every card in both decks is cross-referenced against MTG lore to build a coherent satirical theology from 200 singleton cards.

items.NAME: ‚ö° AzureMLOps
items.TITLE: MSFT Internship
items.MOTTO: Streamlining & expediting CI/CD workflows
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Azure ML Operationalization replaces agent-bound CI/CD with an agentless pipeline: Azure DevOps triggers an Azure Service Bus message, which fires an Azure Function that submits notebook Runs directly to Azure ML Compute. Notebooks validate without queuing behind other builds, and failures surface as DevOps Test Runs for debugging in the pipeline UI.

How It Works

Three moving parts: an agentless DevOps Pipeline publishes a message to Azure Service Bus via PublishToAzureServiceBus@1, an Azure Function (run_notebook_service_bus) picks it up and orchestrates the run, and Azure ML Compute executes the notebook. The Function authenticates to the ML Workspace via Service Principal, fetches the target repository, injects try-catch callbacks around each notebook cell for completion signaling, submits Runs with configurable compute targets and Conda environments, and polls for results. When runs finish, the Function posts Test Run results, attachments, and status updates back to DevOps via the REST API, then closes the pipeline with a callback. A separate agent-based deployment pipeline handles pytest unit testing, packaging, and AzureFunctionApp@1 deployment.

The Grind

The codebase is split into focused handler modules: azureml_handler.py (Workspace auth, Experiment/Run/RunConfig management), devops_handler.py (pipeline callbacks, Test Run CRUD, attachments, repository downloads), file_handler.py (staging, snapshot builds, Conda dependency injection, notebook callback injection/removal), and notebook_handler.py (cell-level code injection and scrubbing). Pipeline configuration is driven by DevOps variables; 20+ parameters covering Service Bus connections, compute targets, Docker images, repository versions, and Service Principal credentials.

items.NAME: üéõ IoT Panel
items.TITLE: Personal Project
items.MOTTO: A thought experiment on UI design & tactility
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Smart home control lives behind glass: flat touchscreens and voice assistants with no tactile feedback. Home Control Panel is a physical control surface built from toggle switches, rotary encoders, sliding potentiometers, and 7-segment displays, wall-mounted in a picture frame. A thought experiment on whether physical controls can coexist with modern home automation.

How It Works

A Raspberry Pi with a 10-inch SunFounder touchscreen serves as the brain, running a web-based UI (index.html + index.css) alongside a Python backend (console.py) and JavaScript controller (console.js) that interface with the physical I/O. The panel has 15 SPST toggle switches with red LED covers, KY-040 rotary encoders with threaded knobs, a double-row sliding linear potentiometer, and a 4-bit 7-segment LED display, all mounted in a Quadro 12√ó20 picture frame backed by a Kydex thermoformable sheet. Total build cost: ~$300.

The Grind

Every component was sourced off Amazon and hand-wired. Toggle switches need satisfying throw, encoders need precise detents, sliders need smooth travel; choosing the right parts took as long as wiring them. The panel controls lights, climate, and media from a single wall-mounted surface.

items.NAME: üèÉ MotleyMoves
items.TITLE: UCM Final Project
items.MOTTO: Providing Modesto Moves an all-in-one platform
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Modesto Moves is a nonprofit training club with 250+ participants across Modesto, Ripon, and Manteca, running everything on pen and paper. We built MotleyMoves to digitize the operation: event planning, participant tracking, check-in/check-out, medical records, and race mapping in one mobile-friendly web app.

How It Works

A serverless C#.NET Azure Function App serves as the API layer, connecting an Azure SQL Database to an HTML/CSS/JS front-end. Google Sign-In handles auth, MapBox renders interactive race course maps with draggable markers for bathrooms, refreshments, and parking, and FullCalendar displays upcoming events. Admins can create events, draw race routes on a map, track attendance with timestamps, and view participant medical info from the browser. We enrolled in Azure Cloud for Nonprofits ($5,000/year in credits) to keep the back-end running at zero cost.

The Grind

The C# back-end has 15+ Azure Function endpoints handling race point CRUD, GPS position updates, medical record management, and attendance tracking. We redesigned the entire administrative workflow, built it with scalability to neighboring communities in mind, and added an attendance incentive system.

items.NAME: üí® Breeze
items.TITLE: Keysight IoT Challenge
items.MOTTO: Promoting air quality awareness is a Breeze
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Breeze turns a smartphone into an IoT air quality sensor by plugging off-the-shelf sensors into the audio aux jack: no Bluetooth pairing, no proprietary hardware, no app downloads. Plug in and start collecting data. A submission to Keysight's IoT Innovation Challenge.

How It Works

Sensor data streams through the aux jack into a web dashboard built on Paper Dashboard, where Mapbox GL JS renders air quality heatmaps with interpolated color ramps (blue for clean, red for hazardous). Users can zoom from a global view down to street level, with the heatmap transitioning to individual data point circles at higher zoom. A Stats page shows historical trends via Chartist.js and a My Device page manages connected sensors.

The Grind

The aux jack approach avoids wireless protocol configuration, companion app installs, and battery-powered sensor nodes. Any phone with a headphone jack becomes a node in a distributed air quality network. The visualization layer is built from GeoJSON data sources with custom heatmap weight, intensity, radius, and opacity interpolations tuned per zoom level.

items.NAME: üíé Firmi
items.TITLE: MACES NASA MUREP
items.MOTTO: Teaching abstract physics through tangible 3D-printed models
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Fermi surfaces define the electronic behavior of metals but are hard to visualize from a textbook. As part of the MACES NASA MUREP experience at UC Merced, we used the Firmi utility to turn Fermi surface data into 3D-printed models for in-classroom teaching.

How It Works

Firmi converts calculated Fermi surfaces into 3D-printable geometry. Starting from electronic structure calculations (Quantum ESPRESSO, Wannier90), the pipeline reads bxsf files in XCrySDen format and applies a Marching Cubes algorithm (implemented in Fortran90) to generate isosurface meshes. The output is an OpenSCAD .scad file that renders the Fermi surface as a solid volume, exported to STL for printing. Examples include fcc copper and fcc lead on 20√ó20√ó20 k-grids.

The Grind

The Marching Cubes implementation handles non-orthogonal parallelipiped reciprocal lattice vectors with periodic boundary conditions and cell translation to close surfaces. Tuning k-grid resolution is a balancing act: too fine and OpenSCAD runs out of memory, too coarse and the physics is lost. The printed models let students rotate a copper Fermi surface in their hands instead of reading about it in a diagram.

items.NAME: üó† Ozone
items.TITLE: Innovate to Grow
items.MOTTO: Accessing sustainability initiatives interactively
items.TEXT:
The Idea

UC Merced's Department of Sustainability had no central way to show students, faculty, and visitors what green initiatives existed on campus or where to find them. Through Engineering Service Learning, we built Ozone: an interactive web app mapping every sustainability resource on campus, designed to live at sustainability.ucmerced.edu/map.

How It Works

A React front-end with three themed Mapbox GL JS maps (Environmental, Economic, and Social), each rendering GeoJSON polygon overlays of campus buildings. Point-of-interest markers are loaded from CSV data via Axios and PapaParse, covering water refill stations, Ozzi reusable container stations, LEED labs, EV charging, bike racks, community gardens, bus stops, gender-neutral bathrooms, and more. Each marker gets a unique Font Awesome icon and color, with popups showing descriptions and locations. The maps support geolocation tracking, navigation controls, and a 3D pitch toggle for building extrusions.

The Grind

Every building on UC Merced's campus is hand-mapped as a GeoJSON polygon with precise coordinates: COB1, COB2, SE1, SE2, Mariposa, Tuolumne, Cathedral, Half Dome, Valley Terrace. Three separate map components each load their own themed CSV datasets and render dozens of categorized markers with custom icon switching. Built on Node/Express with Jest testing.

items.NAME: ‚Ñπ Iterate
items.TITLE: Mobile App Challenge
items.MOTTO: The Rosetta Stone of Programming
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Iterate is a mobile code editor that uses Java/Arduino syntax but lets you build programs through guided tap-based selections instead of raw typing. It sits between block-based tools like Scratch and writing real code. Built for UC Merced's CITRIS Mobile App Challenge.

How It Works

Built in Unity with C#, the app runs on a 1,300+ line CodeManager that acts as both editor and interpreter. Users tap a line to enter edit mode, then construct code through cascading option menus: Create Variable ‚Üí Integer/Double/Boolean/String ‚Üí name it ‚Üí assign a value. Flow control (if/else, while, for loops), Arduino hardware calls (pinMode, digitalWrite, analogRead, analogWrite, Serial.begin/print/println, servo.attach/write, delay, map), and variable scoping are all handled through the same tap-driven UI. A ColorCoder class provides real-time syntax highlighting (keywords in blue, objects in teal, strings in amber, comments in green) by injecting Unity rich text color tags on every frame. Pre-built lesson templates (Windmill, Servos, Stopwatch) load from Resources as starting scaffolds.

The Grind

The editor tracks variable scope by scanning every line above the cursor for declarations, dynamically populating only valid options at each step; you cannot write a syntax error. The whole thing compiles to WebGL for in-browser play on any device. $5,000 Grand Prize at the 2017 CITRIS Mobile App Challenge. Try it live ‚Üí

items.NAME: üêï Dog Park
items.TITLE: Pitchfest
items.MOTTO: Tinder for pet adoption
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Millions of shelter animals are euthanized every year because the adoption process is inconvenient, not because they're unadoptable. DogPark applies the Tinder swipe model to pet adoption: browse shelter animal profiles, match with ones that fit your lifestyle, and connect with the shelter directly.

How It Works

A mobile-first swipe interface surfaces shelter animal profiles with photos, temperament info, and compatibility details. Users swipe right on animals they're interested in, building a shortlist. The app connects shelters with potential adopters who don't know where to start, reducing the friction between wanting a pet and actually going to a shelter.

The Grind

Pitched at UC Merced's Pitchfest 2016, selected as a Finalist. Most of the work was in framing the problem and the pitch itself rather than building out a full product.

items.NAME: ‚ö° AMAX ESD
items.TITLE: FIRST Robotics, AMAX
items.MOTTO: ESD for AMAX's ISO 9001 manufacturing
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Electrostatic discharge damages server components in ways that don't show up until well short of expected MTBF. As an ISO 9001 manufacturer building servers for Fortune 500 brands, AMAX needed to detect ESD bracelet disconnections instantly on a busy production floor. FIRST Robotics Team 1458 (the Red Ties) took the project.

In school, we learn a lot of theoretical principles. Our participation in FRC has allowed us to put those theories into practice, but in a game environment. This project with AMAX has taken that one step further and allowed us to understand these principles in a real-world situation.

David Hungerman (brother), FRC 1458

How It Works

Standard ESD bracelets wired through analog ESD monitors with connectivity to LED light poles. When an operator's bracelet loses ground (disconnected or improperly seated) the light pole fires immediately, giving floor-wide visual identification. No software lag, no manual checks: automated monitoring that integrates into AMAX's existing assembly lines.

We are very proud of the members of Team 1458 for accomplishing this project with AMAX. The mission of FIRST is to inspire young people to be science and technology leaders by building skills just like this. The fact that these students were able to put those skills into practical use so early in their careers is a testament to the success of FIRST. This just underscores that FIRST is about more than robots.

Jim Beck, California Senior Regional Director, US FIRST

The Grind

High school students solving a real manufacturing problem for a real company. We went from classroom principles to a product AMAX deployed on their production lines.

items.NAME: ü¶æ MotorSkills
items.TITLE: SLO Hacks
items.MOTTO: ML-driven Intelligence for Industrial IoT
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Inspired by many a destroyed DC motor. A broken motor on an assembly line costs thousands in downtime and repairs. MotorSkills monitors industrial motors with ML: automated diagnostics, malfunction corrections, and push notifications before failures cascade.

How It Works

We read amperage and RPM data from motors and feed it into Google AutoML. Time-series sensor readings are converted into miniature images and run through an image classifier to detect anomalies like stalls and load spikes. Results are displayed in a front-end UI and trigger push notifications for critical issues. The back-end runs on Node.JS with serverless function calls and parallel clustering to handle Bluetooth sensor comms alongside AutoML.

The Grind

We generated our own training data by physically stalling, overloading, and abusing DC motors with custom hardware to learn what good training data actually looks like. Wiring together most of the GCP suite into one hardware app earned us Best Use of GCP.

items.NAME: ‚õΩ GasLeek
items.TITLE: ValleyHacks
items.MOTTO: Applying linear regression to gas prices to help save money at the pump
items.TEXT:
The Idea

3.5 million truckers refuel 130+ times a year; even a few cents per gallon adds up to billions. GasLeek forecasts gas price trends with machine learning so drivers can time their fill-ups. The acronym: Gas LinEar rEgression Kode.

How It Works

An LSTM neural network trained on historical weekly gas price data, converting time-series readings into supervised learning problems with differencing and MinMax scaling. The model outputs persistence forecasts and projected savings, visualized on a React dashboard (Chart.js) with weekly, monthly, and annual price views, a MapBox gas station map, and a volatility-based savings calculator.

The Grind

The full pipeline runs from raw CSV parsing in Python through a Keras LSTM model to a live React front-end pulling data via Axios; two separate stacks wired into one product. We dealt with TensorFlow setup, DeckGL map layers, and real-time CSV parsing, and took First Place.

items.NAME: üß™ ChemisTRY
items.TITLE: CruzHacks
items.MOTTO: AR project-based learning for chemistry
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Physical project-based learning kits are expensive and single-use; most schools can't afford them. We built a digital alternative: AR lesson plans covering the same standards-aligned chemistry curriculum at a fraction of the cost. Students interact with Amazon Alexa in a 3D chemistry sandbox to explore exothermic reactions and radioactivity from their classroom.

How It Works

AR.JS handles the augmented reality layer on a Node.JS back-end wired into a full AWS stack: the AWS SDK, Lambda for serverless compute, DynamoDB for NoSQL storage, and the Alexa Developer Console for voice interaction. Point a classroom webcam at a marker, talk to Alexa, and the 3D chemistry scene loads in-browser.

The Grind

Most of the time went into maintaining a secure connection between Alexa and a classroom webcam through AWS; getting that many AWS services to talk to each other took longer than building the AR itself. The end result is a working proof of concept that replaces static videos with interactive AR.

items.NAME: ü¶ø SRIRACHA
items.TITLE: SDHacks
items.MOTTO: Search & Rescue Informatic Robot Assistant Clearing Hazardous Areas
items.TEXT:
The Idea

After Indonesia's earthquake, first responders were searching collapsed buildings with no structural information. SRIRACHA (Search and Rescue Informatic Robot Assisting in Charting Hazardous Areas) is an RC tank with an oscillating range-finder that enters first and constructs 3D point clouds of the structure in real time.

How It Works

An Arduino Mega drives the tank and its sweeping range-finder, streaming sensor data over Bluetooth (HC-06) to a Node.JS server via a custom serial communication protocol. JavaScript parses the incoming data and Pixi.JS renders it into a live 3D point cloud visualization: a map of the building as the robot explores it.

The Grind

Serial communication was the main problem; we burned through multiple libraries before landing on SerialPort for low-level Bluetooth access and real-time data streaming. We wrote our own communication protocol from scratch, which meant learning networking fundamentals by debugging them. SD Hacks mentors helped with Node.JS file streaming and wireless strategy; we took Third Place.

items.NAME: üöú SMARTank
items.TITLE: HackFresno
items.MOTTO: An autonomous soil moisture sensing robot, reducing the barrier of entry to IOT farming
items.TEXT:
The Idea

UC Merced sits in California's agricultural heartland, so we built an IoT farming tool. Mapping soil moisture across a field normally requires thousands of sensors. SMARTank replaces them with one autonomous robot that roves the land and probes as it goes.

How It Works

A retrofitted RC tank running on Arduino with upgraded control systems. It traverses farmland, probing soil at regular intervals to record moisture levels and build a data map that would otherwise take a grid of fixed sensors to produce.

The Grind

Power management was the main issue; our components demanded more amperage than our supply could deliver, forcing constant trade-offs between capability and what the hardware could sustain. We got it working and took home Best Hardware Hack.

items.NAME: üë®‚Äçü¶Ø BlindSight
items.TITLE: CitrusHack
items.MOTTO: Giving the visually-impaired haptic sight
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Two teams with the same idea merged to build a wearable haptic system for the visually impaired. An ultrasonic sensor on a stepper motor scans the environment and translates distances into vibrations through an array of haptic modules, all mounted on a top hat.

How It Works

Built on a Raspberry Pi with 3D-printed parts and a vibration motor array. The ultrasonic sensor sweeps on a stepper motor, mapping distances from the body and converting them into haptic feedback in real time. We traded sensor precision for responsiveness; the system was reactive enough to detect someone stepping into your path.

The Grind

A Qualcomm board that refused to connect to WiFi, vague wiring bugs that ate hours, and constant trade-offs between precision and speed. We navigated a hallway eyes-closed using nothing but vibrations, which was enough to validate the concept. Third Place.

items.NAME: üß≠ SeeR√§uber
items.TITLE: SacHacks
items.MOTTO: Polygonal pirates prowling the Pacific
items.TEXT:
The Idea

SeeR√§uber is a pirate strategy game where you write code to build ships, direct fleets, and govern an empire. A tarot system introduces randomness: each card draw can disrupt your plans, forcing you to adapt your code on the fly. The game sits between programming puzzle and resource management.

How It Works

Built in Unity3D with C#. A custom visual programming language uses drag-and-drop code blocks with loops, conditionals, tasks, and variables to control your pirate crew's AI. Each pirate has simulated needs (hunger, thirst, sleep, sailing) and an interpreter evaluates your nested code blocks to generate task queues in real time. A state machine tracks day/night cycles, combat, and sailing conditions, with procedurally generated pirate names and Shakespearean insults.

The Grind

We built a code interpreter from scratch in 24 hours: a recursive block evaluator that parses nested conditionals, loops, and boolean expressions to drive pirate AI. The drag-and-drop UI, need system, and state machine all had to connect into one game loop in a single sprint. Second Place at SacHacks with a playable WebGL build.

items.NAME: üåæ GISt
items.TITLE: HackDavis
items.MOTTO: AR to fill in the missing link from farm-to-table
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Most people have no idea where their produce comes from, which means they have no idea about its environmental impact either. GISt is a farm-to-table AR app: point your phone at produce and see where your food was grown, how it got to you, and what that journey cost the planet.

How It Works

AR powered by Vuforia through Unity3D, with UX prototyped in Axure RP 8 and built in C#. Farm data, GIS layers, and maps are pulled live via the OSIsoft API, MapBox, JavaScript, and JSON, overlaid onto real-world products through the camera feed.

The Grind

Android SDK and Java JDK errors ate most of the early hours on the mobile build. The working prototype had to juggle three separate APIs (AR, mapping, farm data) across different platforms and languages. Best Environment Hack.

items.NAME: ü•´ DigestQuest
items.TITLE: HackMerced
items.MOTTO: OCR as a FitBit for your stomach
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Snap a photo of a nutrition label and DigestQuest breaks down your diet calorie by calorie. No manual entry: point your phone camera at the label and the app reads it for you.

How It Works

A web app built around Tesseract's JavaScript OCR API. Raw OCR output is messy, so we wrote a custom heuristic algorithm that applies representativeness matching to map garbled text to actual nutritional values. Parsed results feed into a back-end database and are visualized in a display designed to be readable at a glance.

The Grind

36 hours of DNS battles and wrangling JQuery and Node.js into talking to Tesseract on a web platform. We walked in barely knowing JavaScript or image processing APIs and left with a working multi-language OCR pipeline and a Best in Design win.

items.NAME: üëë The Nobles
items.MOTTO: Commander Deck
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Edgar Markov's archetypal death-of-the-king warps holy matrimony into massacre. The Nobles is a Mardu Vampires Commander deck built around Edgar's eminence ability: every vampire you cast summons another, turning a trickle of creatures into a flood. The deck is a player-designed game in itself ‚Äî a strategic puzzle of 100 cards engineered to overwhelm through anthems, token doublers, and aristocratic drain loops.

How It Works

Anthems (Legion Lieutenant, Stromkirk Captain, Cordial Vampire) stack to make every 1/1 token lethal. Token doublers (Anointed Procession, Ojer Taq) multiply Edgar's eminence triggers exponentially. Drain engines (Blood Artist, Sanctum Seeker, Vito, Thorn of the Dusk Rose) convert every creature entering and leaving the battlefield into life swings. A full tutor suite (Demonic, Vampiric, Imperial Seal) finds the right piece for any board state. Est. ~$1,500 ¬∑ Bracket 4 (Optimized).

The Grind

100-card singleton deckbuilding is its own design discipline: every slot is a tradeoff between synergy, consistency, and resilience. The Nobles went through dozens of iterations ‚Äî cutting pet cards, rebalancing the mana curve, testing anthem density against removal density ‚Äî before landing on a list that reliably executes its gameplan across a four-player table. The full decklist is documented card-by-card in the MTG section.

items.NAME: üëπ The Demons
items.MOTTO: Commander Deck
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Clavile√±o's descent invokes katabasis: Erebos standing where Aclazotz lies. The Demons is an Orzhov Aristocrats Commander deck built around Clavile√±o, First of the Blessed ‚Äî a commander who blesses vampires with death triggers that replace them with 4/3 flying Demons and draw cards. Sacrifice is the engine, not the cost.

How It Works

Sacrifice outlets (The Golden Throne, Phyrexian Tower, Pyre of Heroes) feed the engine. Recursion (Helm of the Host, Lifeline, Luminous Broodmoth, Reanimate) brings creatures back for repeated death triggers. Stax (Contamination, Dictate of Erebos) turns your sacrifices into opponents' losses. Drain (Vito, Carmen, Twilight Prophet) closes the game. Six tutors and Bola's Citadel ensure consistency. Est. ~$2,000 ¬∑ Bracket 4 (Optimized).

The Grind

The Demons is the darker sibling ‚Äî where The Nobles swarm wide, The Demons grind deep. Every card death is value: Clavile√±o replaces it, aristocrats drain from it, recursion loops it back. The design challenge was building a sacrifice engine that doesn't stall when opponents remove Clavile√±o, solved through redundant death-trigger payoffs and a recursion package that operates independently of the commander. The full decklist is documented card-by-card in the MTG section.

items.NAME: üìú PopVuj
items.MOTTO: City Builder
items.TEXT:
The Idea

'This is the account of how all was in suspense, all calm, in silence; all motionless, quiet, and empty was the expanse of the sky.' Inspired by the Popol Vuh, the Mayan creation narrative. PopVuj is a god-sim where you rule from the heavens, shaping a minion village against rival civilizations through decrees, prophecy, and nature itself. You never lift a sword; you bend fate.

How It Works

The camera is the cosmology. Up into the skies is the seat of divine control: issue decrees, manipulate weather, survey your dominion. Down at the village floor you inspect growth, population, and influence the macro world. Zoom further into individual houses, chapels, and buildings to watch your people interact, worship, and live their lives. Combat draws from VooDoo's minion-swarming system; visuals target Aufstand-style 2.5D graphics. Gods act through second-hand tools: send prophets to deliver messages, smite the unreligious, unleash bears on heretics, summon rain, and shape weather. Minions have traits, personalities, and a genetics system; religiousness is heritable, so selective breeding lets you cultivate a pious (or rebellious) civilization across generations. More religion means more control but less freedom and less science; the tension is the game.

The Grind

The foundation is organized, modular code: clean separation of UIs, dialogue systems, minion AI, genetics, and world simulation. The scope is enormous. A macro-scale rival-village strategy layer, a micro-scale life simulation, and a divine intervention toolkit all need to work together. Early development is focused on getting the core minion loop (birth, traits, needs, faith, death) running before layering on god powers and inter-village warfare. The Popol Vuh itself is the design document: Tzacol, Bitol, Alom, Qaholom tried mud, then wood, then finally corn to shape humanity. Expect a few failed prototypes before the corn catches.

items.NAME: ‚òÑ BitNaughts
items.MOTTO: Code Gamified
items.TEXT:
The Idea

BitNaughts is a free-to-play educational programming video game: code gamified. Construct your object-oriented spaceship, learn programming to code your systems, and save the Earth from Martian invasion. Born from Iterate's interpreter and refined across four consecutive Microsoft Hackathons, BitNaughts turns real coding into real gameplay.

How It Works

Built in Unity 6.0 with C#, the project is organized as a set of Git submodules: a Unity project (bitnaughts.unity), a custom C# interpreter (bitnaughts.interpreter) that steps through each OP Code of abstracted languages, a WebGL front-end (bitnaughts.github.io) for browser-based play, a serverless Azure back-end (bitnaughts.mainframe) for persistence, and separate repos for assets, UI/UX, and components. Players write actual code to control their ship's systems (navigation, weapons, shields) with the interpreter evaluating their programs in real time against the game's physics and combat engine.

The Grind

Four Microsoft Hackathon pitches ('20, '21, '22, '23) shaped the vision through iterative live-demo feedback, each year pushing the architecture further: from a monolithic prototype to a fully modular, open-source game engine. The submodule architecture means contributors can clone, modify, and submit changes to any layer independently. The core challenge remains the same one Iterate cracked: making programming genuinely fun, not just gamified busywork. Play the demo ‚Üí

items.NAME: üå∏ Graviton
items.MOTTO: Tower Defense
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Classic arcade games like Space Invaders and Missile Command never stopped being fun; they just stopped being made. Graviton combines slow-descending alien swarms with strategic satellite defense: a retro sci-fi tower defense game built from scratch at a hackathon.

How It Works

Built in Unity with C#. A 630+ line GameManager handles wave spawning, path generation, satellite placement, and an in-game economy. 5 escalating levels, each a procedurally timed sequence of ship deployments using randomized ship types with distinct scale, speed, and health values. Players purchase and place orbital satellites via a rocket launch animation system. Satellites come in 3 weapon tiers (ConventionalRifle, PlasmaCannon, LaserBeam), each upgradeable for damage and range. Turret rotation uses predictive lead-target aiming, calculating intercept angles from projectile speed, distance, and enemy velocity. The ProjectileManager pools 6 projectile types plus 50 explosion instances with randomized animator controllers. An intro scene plays a radio dialogue cutscene with a Scrambler text effect before dropping into gameplay. Sprites in Paint.NET, audio in Audacity, 12+ ship variants.

The Grind

Two thousand lines of C# in under two days. The lesson: build the skeleton first. We burned hours on animations and sound effects that only slowed debugging. The win screen says it all: 'The Scientists got the Graviton Accelerator running, repelling the Alien Invasion!' Starting from nothing and shipping a game with cutscenes, 5 winnable waves, upgrade trees, and pooled particle explosions in a hackathon window teaches you what to cut and what to keep.

items.NAME: üïπÔ∏è SpaceNinjas
items.MOTTO: 2D Platformer
items.TEXT:
The Idea

Teaching game design means giving students something they can break apart and rebuild. SpaceNinjas is a 2D side-scrolling ninja platformer built as a boilerplate for Monte Vista's Summer of Game Design: a ready-made Unity project students crack open on day one to learn C# by tweaking a working game instead of staring at blank scripts.

How It Works

Built in Unity 5 with C#. The repo ships two parallel script architectures. The first is a fully hardcoded reference game (player.cs at 269 lines, enemy.cs, enemyRanged.cs) with every mechanic inline and heavily commented: A/D movement, W/Space jump via Rigidbody2D.AddForce, left-click sword swing using Physics2D.Raycast, right-click throwing stars via Instantiate. Melee enemies chase via sight-distance detection and swing with raycasts; ranged enemies fire laser projectiles while keeping distance. The second architecture is a set of modular Person_ components (Person_Health, Person_AttackMelee, Person_AttackRanged, Movement_SideScroller, Movement_TopDown, MovementAI_SideScroller, MovementAI_TopDown) with public bool toggles (AI_enabled, SFX_enabled, death_reset, death_deletion) so students compose behaviors via the Unity Inspector without touching code. 3 HP hearts, 3 ammo stars, a cameraFollow script, moving island platforms, and a Dojo finish trigger round out the package.

The Grind

The dual-architecture approach (one monolithic 'here is the whole game' script and one modular 'drag-and-drop behaviors' toolkit) meant writing every system twice. But that's the teaching trick: students see the messy reality first, then learn why components exist. Every line is commented like a textbook. A student who has never opened Unity can play the game in five minutes and start modifying it in ten.

items.NAME: ‚ú® VooDoo
items.MOTTO: Side-Scrolling Auto-Battler
items.TEXT:
The Idea

VooDoo is a side-scrolling lane-pusher in the spirit of Age of War: you spawn pixel-art warriors, set their waypoints across procedurally generated terrain, and watch your tribe clash with waves of voodoo-cursed enemies. You never fight directly; you point and your warband marches. When only the boss remains, you take direct platformer control.

How It Works

Four warrior classes: shield-bearing Farmers, sword-wielding Soldiers, spell-casting Priests, and elite horned Witchdoctors, each hand-sprited with idle, march, and attack animations. Click the terrain to set waypoints; your minions march, fight, and die on their own. The battlefield is procedurally assembled from tile-sets of grassy slopes, dirt flats, and jagged transitions, so no two levels look the same. An 11-level campaign across 3 acts builds to boss encounters where the game switches genres: direct platformer control, dodging thrown swords and targeted explosions in multi-phase arena fights. Two complementary tactics emerge: Towering (stack ranged units behind melee walls) and Rushing (flood the lane with expendable fighters). A continuous survival mode ramps the spawn rate until your tribe finally falls.

The Grind

Hand-animated in Paint.NET from open-source assets: four warrior classes across multiple animation states, three tiers of enemies, and three distinct bosses. Scripted cutscenes, a 16-phase interactive tutorial, and persistent kill/death tracking across all 11 levels. Way too big for a student project. The scope was absurd, the variable names are irreverent, and the codebase has scars; but every level plays to completion and every boss goes down.

items.NAME: üåå GalConq
items.MOTTO: Procedural Space Strategy
items.TEXT:
The Idea

A 4X-style space strategy game where you manage star systems, trade routes, and fleets across a procedurally generated galaxy. Enter orbit to buy and sell ships, send convoys to trade scrap and materials, hire employees and gather intel. Originally built in VB.NET with WinForms as a high-school project.

How It Works

The original 2014 build used VB.NET and WinForms: a procedural 10√ó10 tile grid of star systems with point-and-click navigation, resource management, and fleet command rendered entirely in GDI+. Each star system offered orbital docking (buy/sell ships, manage cargo), convoy routing (trade scrap, materials, and damaged ships between systems), and crew management (hire employees, find mechanics, gather gossip and trade information). The Unity port expanded the scope from 100 fixed tiles to thousands of procedurally generated stars, nebulae, and clusters, with galaxy-wide parameter tuning for the procedural engine: star density, cluster distribution, resource scarcity, and faction territories all configurable.

The Grind

Galactic Conquest was the origin point. The procedural generation engine and the dream of coding-as-gameplay planted the seeds that grew into Iterate's interpreter and eventually BitNaughts. Development paused when the vision shifted; rather than building another space game, the real value was in morphing the project toward educational programming, filling the procedural universe with player-written code instead of scripted AI. The VB.NET prototype proved the concept; BitNaughts is where it landed.

items.NAME: üëë The Nobles
items.TITLE: üßõ Edgar Markov
items.MOTTO: Edgar's archetypal death-of-the-king warps holy matrimony into massacre
items.TEXT:
Mardu Vampires: Edgar's eminence summons waves of vampires.

Anthem: Lieutenant, Captain, Cordial, Drana, Heir, Patchwork & Vanquisher Banner, March.

Tokens: Procession, Ojer Taq, Charmed Groom, Mavren Fein, Announcement.

Scaling: Throne, Bloodletter, Conqueror, Exquisite Blood.

Ramp: Ring, Signet, Horn, Tile, Seal, Vessel, Tithe, Connections.

Tutors: Demonic, Enlightened, Vampiric, Seal, Forerunner.

Protection: Akroma's Will, Unmaking, Doom, Damn, Ultimatum, Rebirth, Reclamation.

Drain: Artist, Seeker, Vito, Thorn & Fanatic, Kamber, Anje.

Draw: Champion, Florian, Bertram, Tarrian's Journal, Mirror.

items.NAME: üëπ The Demons
items.TITLE: üßõ Clavile√±o
items.MOTTO: Clavile√±o's descent invokes katabasis: Erebos standing where Aclazotz lies
items.TEXT:
Orzhov Aristocrats: Clavile√±o's blessing weaponizes death itself.

Sacrifice: Throne, Tower, Pyre, Aristocrat, Heart, Dictate, Butcher, Master.

Denial: Contamination, Anowon, Erebos, Thoughtseize.

Recurral: Helm, Lifeline, Whip, Broodmoth, Bishop, Reanimate, Victimize, Rebirth, Awakening.

Ramp: Ring, Signet, Jet & Pearl Medallion, Ritual, Thought Vessel, Citadel, City, Nykthos.

Tutors: Demonic, Enlightened, Grim, Vampiric Tutors, Seal, Entomb.

Protection: Unmaking, Damn, Fell, Flare, Shadowspear, Greed, Lawbringer.

Drain: Seeker, Vito, Carmen, Prophet.

Draw: Bertram, Archive, Prophet, Preacher.
